answerText: restriction enzymes [or restriction endonucleases][10] Restriction enzymes can cut both strand at the same nucleotide, forming "blunt" ends, or a few nucleotides down on one strand, forming this kind of ends.
heading: NASAT |2013 | 10 | 10 | Science | Biology | College
subject: Science
question: Question: Examples include HindII and EcoRI. For 10 points each: [10] Name these enzymes which cut DNA at specific sequences. They are used in a digest before electrophoresis.
